title: Bayesian Probability Fundamentals
description: Core concepts of Bayesian probability and inference including Bayes' theorem and conditional probability.
learning_objectives: State Bayes' theorem and understand its components
Calculate posterior probabilities from prior and likelihood
Understand the Bayesian interpretation of probability

content.overview: Bayesian probability provides a framework for updating beliefs based on new evidence. It treats probability as a measure of uncertainty about the world, which can be updated as new information becomes available.

conditional_probability.interpretation: Probability of A given B has occurred

probability_interpretations.example: Probability of heads is 0.5 based on many coin flips
Probability of rain is 0.7 based on current evidence

examples.name: Spam Filtering
examples.interpretation: 95.2% chance email is spam given word 'free'

updating_beliefs.evidence_accumulation: Multiple pieces of evidence multiply likelihoods
updating_beliefs.prior_selection: Prior encodes domain knowledge and assumptions

connections_to_active_inference.belief_updating: Core mechanism for inference in Active Inference
connections_to_active_inference.perception: Sensory data updates beliefs via Bayesian inference
connections_to_active_inference.learning: Model parameters updated through Bayesian learning
connections_to_active_inference.decision_making: Action selection based on posterior beliefs

interactive_exercises.description: Practice applying Bayes' theorem to various problems
Calculate conditional probabilities in different scenarios

common_misconceptions.clarification: Priors can be subjective beliefs or objective frequencies

common_misconceptions.misconception: Frequentist and Bayesian methods are incompatible
common_misconceptions.clarification: They answer different questions but can complement each other
